summary: the causal pathogen, FMDV, belongs to the genus Aphthovirus of the family Picornaviridae. the virion has a high potential for genetic and antigenic variation. vaccines employed to control FMD are inactivated and contain the whole virus in a semi-purified state. lactobacillus plantarum is a lactic acid bacterium present in many ecological niches including naturally fermented food and decaying plant materials. it is considered a probiotic, and its high survival rate within GI-tract makes this bacterium a promising candidate for acceptability as a vehicle for in situ delivery of therapeutically interesting proteins [9–11]. female guinea pigs weighing 250 to 300g were kept under pathogen-free conditions with free access to pathogen-free food and water. the daily food and PBMCs isolated from guinea pigs 30 days after first immunization were labeled with CFSE. antibody responses of guinea pigs orally immunized with NC8-pSIP411-VP1 or WCFS1-pSIP411-VP1 showed higher FMDV-neutralizing activity than the control groups’ responses. guinea pigs were challenged with 100 GPID50 (50% guinea pigs infectious dose) of homotypic virus on day 30 after the first immunization. animals showing FMD-compatible lesions only at the original injection site were judged to be protected. those showing any FMD clinical signs in the other three feet as second vesicles were judged to be unprotected. Vaccination is the main prophylactic method of preventing FMDV infection. WCFS1, the first genome annotated Lactobacillus strain, was found that it possessed the functionality of homologous signal peptides sequence. lactobacilli as live vectors can persist longer in the GI-tract and some of them have intrinsic probiotic properties. the partial or complete VP1 coding sequence has been used in the development of engineering vaccines accommodating the large-scale production of recombinant protein. studies are currently underway to employ lactic acid bacteria vectors to produce vaccines of many viral proteins. plantarum can induce sIgA antibodies which are considered to be a major effector in the adaptive immune defense of the respiratory mucosa. this study demonstrated that high levels of FMDV-specific IgA were produced in serum, saliva and feces. but the full mechanisms underlying the decrease in respiratory tract infections are still uncertain. studies will explore immune effects of other FMDV gene segments in combination immunologic adjuvants (iFN) expressed by LAB via mucosal routes in different animal models. despite good application prospect of rLAB as therapeutic tools for safe and efficient use, many questions remain unanswered.
